row.creditLine: Bequest of Eleanor Harter McFarland of Kalamazoo, Michigan, a former resident of Indianapolis, who studied at the Herron School of Art

row.title: Gray Day in Normandy
row.creditLine: Gift of Allen B. Schroeder

row.title: Portrait of Alexander Ernestinoff
row.creditLine: Gift of the Friends of American Art

row.title: Portrait of Anton Scherrer
row.creditLine: Gift of Mrs. Wayman Adams

row.title: Woman in White
row.creditLine: Gift of Mrs. Albert E. Metzger in memory of Albert E. Metzger

row.title: The Artist's Mother, Sarah Swaim Chase
row.creditLine: Gift of Mrs. Carrie Chase Roberts
row.galleryLabel: The artist's mother was the first guest and subject of the first portrait the artist painted in his new studio and summer residence at Shinnecock, Long Island, in 1892. The lace cap was added by Chase to cover a spot he had overlooked, but its delicate texture and bow also soften the sitter's features. Chase taught the first outdoor school of landscape painting at Shinnecock.
row.provenance: Owned by Mrs. Carrie Chase Roberts, sister of the artist

row.title: Portrait of My Father, David H. Chase
row.creditLine: Gift of Mrs. Carrie Chase Roberts

row.title: Moses Swaim
row.creditLine: Mr. and Mrs. Julius F. Pratt Fund

row.title: The Temple of Philae
row.creditLine: Gift of Margaret C. Pratt

row.title: Halloween Carnival
row.creditLine: Gift of Mrs. Henrik Martin Mayer

row.title: Sacred Waters
row.creditLine: The Harrison Eiteljorg Gallery of Western Art
row.galleryLabel: Couse is best known for his intimate images of Native Americans in quiet repose. The artist's paint strokes set up a rhythmic flow, which moves throughout the work. Tradition holds that the Taos Indians were created out of the sacred waters of Blue Lake.

row.title: Indian Pueblos
row.creditLine: Gift of the Harrison Eiteljorg Gallery of Western Art
row.galleryLabel: Fechin developed a dramatic style consisting of vigorous brush strokes and vivid colors. The artist loved the somber forests near his home in Russia and found their equivalent in the New Mexico Plateau, where he settled in 1927. The Pueblo Indians rekindled Fechin's interest in the culture and heritage of native peoples.

row.title: Crest of the Wave
row.creditLine: Gift of Dr. Steven Conant in honor of Mr. and Mrs. H.L. Conant

row.title: Out of Work
row.creditLine: Gift of Miss Lena L. Ingraham

row.title: Jacob and His Sheep
row.creditLine: Gift of Ann and Joseph Edelman

row.title: Jacob's Angel
row.creditLine: Gift of Ann and Joseph Edelman

row.title: Baseball
row.creditLine: Onya Latour Collection

row.title: Borzois and I
row.creditLine: Gift of Ann and Joseph Edelman

row.title: Untitled Landscape
row.creditLine: Jacob Metzger Memorial Fund

row.title: Winter Landscape
row.creditLine: Indianapolis Museum of Art, Gift of the Indianapolis Chapter of Links

row.title: Henry James, Sr.
row.creditLine: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Bott Duveneck

row.title: Portrait of Squire Duveneck
row.materials: oil on canvas mounted to Plexiglas
row.creditLine: Gift of Dr. Steven Conant in honor of Mr. and Mrs. H.L. Conant

row.title: Mirror III
row.creditLine: Gift of Edwin F. Koch, Jr., M.D.

row.title: The Edge of Town
row.creditLine: Gift of Mrs. Grant W. Christian

row.title: The Painter Man
row.creditLine: Gift of Mrs. James W. Fesler to the Art School of Indianapolis

row.title: Portia in a Pink Blouse
row.creditLine: Gift of Mrs. Booth Tarkington
row.galleryLabel: Portia's fashionable hat, with its veil stretched tightly over her face and head, is in keeping with Du Bois' tendency to reduce human forms to a few simplified shapes. The sitter is dressed in a style that echoes her high social standing. Du Bois was an art critic as well as an artist.
row.provenance: Sold by Newhouse Galleries in New York as part of the Newton Booth Tarkington estate 1952

row.title: The Black Barn
row.creditLine: Martha Delzell Memorial Fund

row.title: From Mount Kearsarge
row.creditLine: Gift of Mrs. James W. Fesler

row.title: The Family Cow
row.creditLine: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Harris P. Byrd

row.title: Still Life: Brass Bowl
row.creditLine: John Herron Fund

row.title: Red Snapper
row.creditLine: Gift in memory of John P. Frenzel, Sr., by his heirs

row.title: Still Life - Brass Kettle and Catfish
row.creditLine: Gift of Dr. and Mrs. Goethe Link

row.title: Two Princesses, Sophia and Amelia, Daughters of His Majesty, King George III
row.creditLine: Gift of Mrs. Herman C. Krannert

row.title: A Lord Mayor of London
row.creditLine: James E. Roberts Fund

row.title: The Art Jury
row.creditLine: Gift to the Art Association through popular subscription
row.galleryLabel: This ambitious portrait presents the members of the Hoosier group, (from left to right) T. C. Steele, Otto Stark, J. Ottis Adams and William Forsyth. Richard Gruelle had died seven years earlier. The artists are posed as if they were choosing paintings for an art exhibition.
row.provenance: Purchased from the artist by a group of local patrons for the museum.

row.title: Morning--Old Schofield's Mill
row.creditLine: Gift of Rosemary A. Gatewood and Kenneth Gatewood

row.title: First Snow of Winter
row.creditLine: Museum Accession

row.title: Portrait of Madame Fisher
row.creditLine: Julius F. Pratt Fund
row.galleryLabel: Eugene Ullman's style resembles that of his teachers, William Merritt Chase and James Abbott McNeill Whistler. In this painting the artist combines the dark tonalities of the figure and background to create an elegant portrait. Ullman spent most of his career in France.

row.title: Portrait of Dr. Charles G. McLean
row.creditLine: Gift of 15 pupils of McLean Seminary

row.title: Waiting and Mad
row.materials: oil on board mounted to masonite
row.creditLine: Gift of the Harrison Eiteljorg Gallery of Western Art
row.galleryLabel: This painting is an Indian-style version of the Oriental harem woman, a voluptuous figure reclining in luxurious surroundings. The title gives the picture a touch of anecdotal humor. Russell and Frederick Remington were the most renowned artists of the American West.

row.title: Francisco Martinez
row.creditLine: Gift of the Harrison Eiteljorg Gallery of Western Art
row.galleryLabel: This is an idealized portrait of a seventeen-year-old Indian boy who later became Chief of the Taos Pueblo. The boy is shown drying a bird's brain to create a talisman that will guarantee his future success. Sharp documented Indian tribal life and ritual.

row.title: Bethlehem
row.creditLine: Delavan Smith Fund

row.title: Mountain Man
row.creditLine: Gift of the Harrison Eiteljorg Gallery of Western Art
row.galleryLabel: Remington portrayed this horse and rider with a keen sense of drama, capturing the perils of descending down a steep mountain slope. This scene is portrayed as realistically as the sculptor's art permits. The West's most daring explorers, trappers, and traders were known as mountain men.

row.title: The Electric Forest
row.creditLine: Gift in memory of Ann Tyndall Durham
row.galleryLabel: The foreboding quality of the forest and the three tiny spotlighted figures, frozen in poses of fright and struggle, suggest the aftermath of a disaster. The use of the explosive material pyroxylin, a fast drying duco, is in keeping with the artist's image of forces beyond man's control.

row.title: Whitewater Rapids
row.creditLine: Bequest of Delavan Smith

row.title: The Constitutional Elm
row.materials: watercolor and gouache on off-white paper
row.creditLine: Gift of Mrs. Addison Bybee

row.title: Portrait of Sally Montgomery
row.creditLine: Bequest of Eleanor Harter McFarland of Kalamazoo, Michigan, a former resident of Indianapolis, who studied at the Herron School of Art

row.title: Portrait of Hugh Montgomery
row.creditLine: Bequest of Eleanor Harter McFarland of Kalamazoo, Michigan, a former resident of Indianapolis, who studied at the Herron School of Art

row.title: The Restless Sea
row.creditLine: Gift of Mrs. James Sweetser

row.title: The Visitation
row.creditLine: Special Fund

row.title: In the Catskills
row.creditLine: Gift of Mrs. John N. Carey

row.title: The Sycamores (Broad Ripple)
row.creditLine: John Herron Fund

row.title: Temperance Pledge
row.creditLine: Gift of Mrs. Morris Clark

row.title: Landscape near Indianapolis
row.creditLine: Bequest of Mr. and Mrs. Hugo Fechtman

row.title: Young German Girl (Gretchen?)
row.creditLine: Gift of Mrs. Samuel Richards

row.title: Old Johnnie's Wife
row.creditLine: Gift of John J. Weldon in memory of his wife, Jean Dinwiddie Weldon
row.galleryLabel: This figure exemplifies the straightforward unidealized portraits favored by Henri. The woman in this canvas lived off the coast of Ireland, where Henri and his wife vacationed. Henri led the Ashcan School, a group of artists who focused on gritty urban realism.
row.provenance: The Estate of Robert Henri; (Chapellier Galleries, New York, New York, exclusive representative since 1963 of the Henri Estate, 1972); John J. Weldon and Jean Dinwiddie Weldon, Chilmark, Massachusetts, December 1972; Indianapolis Museum of Art

row.title: Portrait of the Artist's Wife
row.creditLine: Gift of Mr. Shirlaw Donnelly Gookins, son of the Artist

row.title: Portrait of Dr. Lewis D. Lyons
row.creditLine: Gift of Roger Gould Wolcott
row.galleryLabel: The seated half-length figure, plain background and emphasis on hands and face are elements of early American portraits. Hoosier artist Barton Hays began his career tinting photographs and painting over enlarged prints.
row.provenance: Purchased by Roger Gould Wolcott at an auction in 1951 where the contents of the Lyon's home were sold in Attica. Recods state that it was in the collection of Minnie Parker of Attica.

row.title: Oaks at Vernon
row.creditLine: John Herron Fund

row.title: In the Parlor
row.creditLine: Julius F. Pratt Fund

row.title: Road in Early Spring
row.creditLine: Purchased from Friends of American Art and Friends of Art

row.title: Politics in an Oyster House
row.creditLine: Delavan Smith Fund

row.title: Bust of President Benjamin Harrison
row.creditLine: Gift of the Harrison Memorial Association

row.title: The Bacidae
row.creditLine: Gift of Richard B. Dodson
row.galleryLabel: In this painting, two soothsayers of ancient Greece, called Bacidae, study the entrails of a bird for signs of the future. Dodson's work is based on dramatic themes from the Bible, history and classical mythology.

row.title: The Jade Bowl
row.creditLine: Gift of the Friends of American Art
row.galleryLabel: Although Dines learned to paint from his Danish-American father, Emile, both artists produced tonal arrangements inspired by James Abbott McNeill Whistler and 17th-century Dutch masters. In this painting, Whistler's influence is especially apparent in the artist's use of a limited palette of yellow, black and green, and the simplified composition.

row.title: Portrait of Helen Miller (Mrs. Charles G. McLean)
row.creditLine: Gift of Fifteen Pupils of McLean Seminary
row.galleryLabel: The sitter is posed in a romantic setting wearing fashionable attire, but Peale did not soften her intense gaze or prominent nose. Helen and her husband founded McLean Seminary, a girls' school in Indianapolis. Peale was a member of a Philadelphia family of prominent American painters.
row.provenance: Painted by commission from the sitter's father, Helen Miller McLean and her husband moved to Indianapolis after 1815. The painting was hung in the McLean Seminary until 1929 when it was donated to the museum by alumni

row.title: Indian Hunter with Dog
row.creditLine: Gift of Miss Mary C. Trees in memory of her father Clyde H. Trees
row.galleryLabel: With its emphasis on profile and clean geometric shapes, Indian Hunter exhibits Manship's enthusiasm for archaic Greek sculpture. The sculpture's rhythmic contours create the sensation of movement. Manship is best known for his gilded statue of Prometheus at Rockefeller Center in New York.

row.title: Liberty Loan Parade
row.creditLine: Martha Delzell Memorial Fund
row.galleryLabel: The fluid brush and broken color, as well as the birds-eye view perspective, all indicate Goodwin's debt to Impressionism. The subject refers to one of the many parades held to raise funds for America's war efforts. This canvas is a view of Arlington Street as it borders Boston Gardens Park.
row.provenance: Purchased from the Graham Gallery in New York 1970

row.title: Untitled
row.creditLine: Mary B. Milliken Fund
row.galleryLabel: Famous for his mobiles and stabiles, the sculptor Alexander Calder was also a notable painter. Calder's work displays a free and whimsical spirit. The two keyhole-shaped vibrantly colored, geometric figures transform a simple design into a dream image.
row.provenance: ...purchased from Ann Kendall Richards in New York 1971; authenticated by Mr. Klaus Perls of Perls Gallery in New York

row.title: Portrait of a Young Woman
row.creditLine: Gift of the Sons of J. Ottis Adams
row.galleryLabel: The portrait is an essay in subtle earth tones accented by the woman’s long dangling earring. The simple flourish that suggests the figure’s right hand demonstrates Bell’s adept brushwork. This figure study exemplifies Bell’s early work and Munich School training.

row.title: The Moose Hunter
row.creditLine: The Orville A. and Elma D. Wilkinson Fund
row.galleryLabel: To emphasize the untouched quality of the American wilderness, Codman dramatized the Indian's prowess in his native environment. This landscape surrounded by trees and mountains is a composite of specific and imagined forms, some drawn from prints and literary sources.
row.provenance: The artist, Victor D. Spark New York City, Theodore Stebbins Jr. Northampton, MA 1967, Robert P. Weiman Woodbridge, CO, Indianapolis Museum of Art 1973

row.title: A Break: Playing Cards
row.creditLine: James E. Roberts and Martha Delzell Memorial Fund

row.title: Portrait of a Young Woman
row.creditLine: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Ball
row.galleryLabel: The sitter's dress and coiffure reflect the new American aristocracy's desire to legitimize itself through association with historical styles of ancient Greece and Rome. Stuart's portraits of George Washington and Federalist families in Philadelphia and Washington secured his place in history.
row.provenance: Purchased from Max Safron of New York by William H. Ball in Muncie, Indiana; Mr. Ball donated it to the museum in 1977

row.title: Venus Anadyomene
row.creditLine: Gift of Dr. and Mrs. M. D. Ratner
row.galleryLabel: The stylized hair and soft rounded forms are in harmony with the images of the sea, the goddess, and Art Deco sculpture of the 1920s and 1930s. This small bronze figure is tied to the mythological goddess of love and her birth from the foam of the sea.
row.provenance: purchased from Galleries Maurice Sternberg

row.title: An Anxious Mother
row.creditLine: Gift of the Girls Classical School
row.galleryLabel: De Luce was a noted portrait and genre painter. An Anxious Mother is a typical Victorian scene of a child at play. This is the first painting acquired by the museum after it was founded in 1883.

row.title: Untitled (The Birth)
row.creditLine: Gift of the National Coalition of 100 Black Women, Indianapolis Chapter, the Alliance of the Indianapolis Museum of Art and the Mr. and Mrs. Richard Crane Fund
row.galleryLabel: This scene is composed of flat, simplified forms, vibrant colors and geometric patterns. Lawrence, one of the nation's most important African American artists, excelled in making paintings and prints of contemporary life. During the Depression Lawrence focused on the tenement house in New York's Harlem.
row.provenance: purchased through Terry Dinten Fass Inc.

row.title: Afternoon Tea
row.creditLine: Partial and Promised Gift of Jane and Andrew Paine
row.galleryLabel: Women in a sunlit landscape framed by a large, vividly patterned Japanese parasol, exemplify Miller's expressionist technique. Miller was one of the American Impressionists working in the French countryside known as the Giverny Group.
row.provenance: Mr. O.J. Wardwell (probably); C.L. Baldwin Esq.; sold through New York American Art Association "Private Collection of Important American Paintings formed by C.L. Baldwin" April 22, 1926; by descent in the family to owner in Connecticut; sold at Christies to the IMA and the Paines at Chirstie's December 4, 1997

row.title: Rooftops, New York City
row.creditLine: Gift of Allethaire Hendricks and Milton Fisk
row.galleryLabel: The sharp lines, geometric shapes and flat areas of color place Rooftops within the Precisionist style. Precisionism was influenced by industrial development, such as skyscrapers and factories, and shows images painted with machine-like quality frozen in time like a photograph.

row.title: The Statuette
row.creditLine: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Mallinson

row.title: Blue Monday
row.creditLine: Bequest of Mrs. Floyd Hopper

row.title: The Park, Salem
row.creditLine: Gift of the Gamboliers
row.galleryLabel: The artist translated the activities of everyday life into a loosely knit tapestry of flat, bold areas of color. Prendergast preferred the medium of watercolor. The site for this watercolor is probably a nature park near Salem, Massachusetts.

row.title: Praying Angel
row.creditLine: Lucy M. Taggart Estate

row.title: Thames Nocturne
row.creditLine: Gift of the Herron Museum Alliance

row.title: EAST COAST U.S.A.
row.creditLine: Gift of Mrs. Paul E. Beem

row.title: Sketch, Hyannisport
row.creditLine: Gift of Mary B. Milliken
row.galleryLabel: With loose, fluid brushstrokes, the artist depicts the boats, cottages, and shore of this harbor, while still emphasizing the flat surface of the canvas Hawthorne studied under William Merritt Chase and helped run Chase’s Long Island school before founding the Cape Cod School of Art in Provincetown, Massachusetts. The town attracted many artists, and Hawthorne became known as the “father” of the art colony. Paintings of Provincetown fishermen executed in a more somber palette so dominate the artist’s work that this lively, vibrant painting of Hyannisport, a town 50 miles away, represents an intriguing contrast.

row.title: Eleanor
row.creditLine: Daniel P. Erwin Fund

row.title: Young Girls
row.creditLine: James E. Roberts Fund
row.galleryLabel: Mary Cassatt received her early training in America, but settled in Paris, where she exhibited with the Impressionists in the late 1870s. Children and motherhood provided the primary themes for Cassatt's work. She successfully avoided sentimentalized views of childhood, focusing instead on her subjects freshness, intelligence and energy. Like her mentor Edgar Degas, Cassatt worked well in pastel, a medium that utilized her drawing skills and refined sense of texture.
row.provenance: Purchased from the Maurice LeClanche collection by Mr. Knoedler for 35,000 francs; Lucy Taggart sent the piece to the John Herron Art Institute to be purchased under the James E. Roberts fund for $3,000

row.title: Hauptmann Must Die
row.creditLine: Bequest of Felicia Meyer Marsh
row.galleryLabel: Marsh employed a graphic, linear technique to bring individuality to the travelers. The newspaper headline refers to the sentencing of the convicted kidnapper of Charles Lindbergh's baby. Marsh's artistic inspiration derived from his study of European Old Master painters.
row.provenance: The artist; the widow of the artist; left to the museum by bequest

row.title: Indian Girl with Parrot and Hoop
row.creditLine: Gift in memory of John P. Frenzel Sr. by his heirs
row.galleryLabel: This canvas, with its intricate linear construction, exhibits the artist's dramatic use of brilliant color. Pueblo people used parrots as a source of feathers to decorate ceremonial objects. Indiana-born Higgins gained his fame as a Western artist painting in Taos, New Mexico.

row.title: Hotel Lobby
row.creditLine: William Ray Adams Memorial Collection
row.galleryLabel: Three nameless guests and a desk clerk occupy the disquieting, airless space of Hotel Lobby. The cheerlessness of the foyer is enhanced by the lack of rapport among the figures. Hopper is renowned for paintings infused with loneliness and banality.
row.provenance:
From the artist to (Frank K.M. Rehn Gallery, New York) in 1943;{1} Mr. and Mrs. Henry R. Hope, Bloomington, Indiana, in 1945;{2} given by them as part of the William Ray Adams Memorial Collection to the John Herron Art Institute (now Indianapolis Museum of Art) in 1947.{3}
{1}See Gail Levin, Edward Hopper: A Catalogue Raisonné, New York, 1995, vol. 3, cat no. O-324, and vol. 4 (CD Rom) reproduces Record Book III, p. 1, indicating it was delivered to Rehn Gallery on 4 January 1943. {2}Ibid., vol 4. A now detached label in IMA Historical File (47.4) indicates that the painting was purchased by the Hopes out of the 56th Annual American Exhibition held at the Art Institute of Chicago in 1945. {3}Mrs. Henry R. Hope, née Sarahanne Adams, was the daughter of William Ray Adams.

row.creditLine: Gift of Anonymous Person

row.title: Portrait of Ella Marvin

row.title: Farmyard Scene
row.creditLine: Gift of Otto R. Lieber

row.title: Portrait of Amelia Studley
row.creditLine: Purchase Fund
row.galleryLabel: In this portrait Eaton's brushstrokes appear loose, but the drawing of the sitter's facial features remains firm and solid. Eaton spent only a short time in Indianapolis, during which he studied under Jacob Cox. He eventually settled in New York. The artist developed a reputation as a skillful painter of women's portraits.
row.provenance: Miss Violet G. Williams of Cincinnati 1934; Edward H. Dwight of Cincinnati; Indianapolis Museum of Art

row.title: San Barnaba
row.creditLine: Gift of the National Academy of Design, Henry Ward Ranger Fund

row.creditLine: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. John G. Rauch, Sr.

row.creditLine: Gift of the Harrison Eiteljorg Gallery of Western Art

row.title: The Beach Scituate, Massachusetts
row.creditLine: The Holliday Collection

row.title: Summer Landscape Falls Village, Connecticut
row.creditLine: Gift of Mrs. Grace Zelms

row.title: Buildings in Winter
row.creditLine: Gift of the Artist

row.title: Unfinished Landscape (American Lake Scene at Sunset)
row.creditLine: Allen Whitehill Clowes Fund

row.title: Landscape
row.creditLine: The Ballard Family Memorial Fund

row.title: Strawberries
row.creditLine: Gift of the Honorable and Mrs. Paul H. Buchanan, Jr.

row.title: Portrait of Eusebia Sewell
row.creditLine: Gift of Miriam L. Luke, Grandniece of Eusebia A. (Luke) and William C.B. Sewell
row.galleryLabel: The dark tonalities and unadorned background are typical of nineteenth century portraiture. The delicate lace neckline fastened with a cameo pin and the tiny drop earring soften the dark tonality of this portrait. The Sewells were residents of Covington, Indiana.
row.provenance: The artist to the Sewells; Mrs. William Wallace Luke (wife of Eusebia's youngest sibling); Mrs. Donald Ferguson ( grand-daughter of William Wallace Luke); Gift of Ms Mariam L. Luke of Covington, Indiana (second grand-daughter of William Wallace Luke)

row.title: Portrait of William Sewell
row.creditLine: Gift of Miriam L. Luke, Grandniece of Eusebia A. (Luke) and William C.B. Sewell
row.galleryLabel: The simple, direct manner, combined with firm brushwork and the careful attention to detail in the sitter's beard, hair and glasses, is evidence of Hays' skill as a portrait painter. Much of Hays' renown came from his having tutored William Merritt Chase, but his reputation rested on the quality of his portraits and fruit still lifes.
row.provenance: The artist to the Sewells; Mrs. William Wallace Luke (wife of Eusebia's youngest sibling); Mrs. Donald Ferguson (grand-daughter of William Wallace Luke); Gift of Ms Miriam L. Luke of Covington, Indiana (second grand-daughter of William Wallace Luke)

row.title: Fairy Marauders

row.title: Hopi Courtship
row.creditLine: Gift of the Harrison Eiteljorg Gallery of Western Art
row.galleryLabel: Leigh was known as the "Sagebrush Rembrandt" due to his use of traditional European techniques. The dark tonalities in this work reflect his training at the Royal Academy in Munich. The artist strongly disliked modern, abstract art. Leigh focused on the culture and traditions of the Hopi and Navajo Indians.

row.galleryLabel: Recognized primarily for his Cubist-inspired sculpture, Archipenko also featured the disjunctive planes and irregular contours of Cubism in his paintings, such as Promenade. Archipenko worked in Europe until emigrating to the United States in 1923.

row.title: Head of Margot
row.materials: pastel on white laid Ingres paper
row.creditLine: Gift of William Mansur Hume
row.galleryLabel: Mary Cassatt received her early training in America but settled in Paris, where she befriended Edgar Degas and exhibited with the Impressionists. Young children were among Cassatt's favorite subjects, though she avoided sentimental portrayals in favor of emphasizing her models' freshness, intelligence, and energy. This pastel is one in a series of portraits of children who lived in the French village where Cassatt spent her summers.

row.title: Provincetown Fisherman
row.creditLine: D.P. Erwin Fund
row.galleryLabel: The stately composition and solid forms give the subject a dignity not often associated with fish markets. Hawthorne's green-toned palette evokes the sea and emphasizes by contrasting color the bloody business at hand. This man was a Portuguese resident of the Cape Cod village where Hawthorne spent most of his career.
row.provenance: The artist; William Macbeth Galleries; IMA in 1916

row.title: Bacchanal (The Four Seasons)

row.creditLine: Gift of the Friends of American Art

row.title: Glow of Gold, Gleam of Pearl
row.creditLine: Gift of Robert Douglas Hunter
row.galleryLabel: Instead of the smooth finish that lends French nudes their remote idealism, this figure is brushed with ruddy reflections of the walls, giving her flesh a sensuous realism, and suggesting Paxton's attraction to Impressionism. A transitional work, this nude predates most of the elegant interior scenes for which Paxton and his Boston School colleagues are best known.
row.provenance: The artist; the wife of the artist and his estate; by bequest to R.H.I. Gammell in Boston, Massachusetts 1971; gift to the museum by Robert Douglas Hunter of Boston 1979

row.title: Winged Form
row.materials: tempera and oil on paper, mounted on canvas
row.creditLine: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence W. long
row.galleryLabel: The subject's origins in nature are suggested through color and texture and the repetition and layering of forms, which create a rhythm reminiscent of fluttering wings. Indiana-born Stevens was originally a landscape painter who eventually produced works that expressed nature in an abstract manner.

row.title: Portrait of John Washington Love
row.creditLine: Gift of Mrs. C. D. Johnson
row.galleryLabel: The casual pose of the portrait allows Love's personality to emerge. The setting may have been a studio in the newly formed Indiana School of Art, the state's first art school. Bates and Love settled in Indianapolis after studying together in Paris.
row.provenance: The painting was donated to the IMA by John Washington Love's sister, Mrs. Charles D. Johnson
